entry.title: Solace to SAP CPI: Step-by-Step Configuration Guide from Scratch : part-2
entry.content:
In this blog, I’ll guide you through setting up Solace from signing up on the solace console to creating queues, Topics and testing message flows. Whether you’re new to event mesh technology or planning to integrate Solace with the sap cpi, this step-by-step guide will help you get started confidently.

Solace Event Broker, also known as Advanced Event Mesh (AEM), enables event-driven architecture by allowing seamless integration between enterprise systems like SAP Cloud Integration (CPI) and message brokers.

Step-1 : Access to the Solace Platform

To get started, visit https://solace.com and click on the Register button and fill the all mandatory credentials and if you have already an account click on the Login button at the top right corner. From there, you can create a free trial account to access the Solace Platform .

Step-2: Sign Up / Log In:

 If you’re new to Solace, click on Sign Up to register as a new user. If you already have an account, simply log in using your valid credentials and Jump to Step4.

Step-3: Provide Valid Sign-Up Details

If you're signing up for the first time, ensure you enter all the required and accurate information during the registration process to successfully create your account.

Step- 4: Access the Solace Console

After successfully logging in, you will be redirected to the Solace platform, where you can begin managing your messaging services.

Step-5:Navigate to Cluster Manager

On the left-hand panel of the Solace Console, under Component Services, click on Cluster Manager.
The Cluster Manager is where you create and manage your Solace messaging services (brokers). It allows you to define the environment, cloud provider, region, and service type to provision a messaging service According to your needs.

Step-6: Create a New Service

To create a new Solace messaging service, click on Create Service and provide the following details:

  • Service Name

  • Environment (e.g., dev, test)

  • Cloud Provider (AWS, Azure, etc.)

  • Region (choose the one closest to your location)

For learning and development purposes, select the Service Type as Developer, which is a free-tier option suitable for testing and non-production use. It allows you to explore key features like topics, queues, and basic message flow without incurring any cost.

Once all the details are filled in, click on Create Service.

Step-7:Service Added to Cluster Manager

Once the service is successfully created, it will appear under the Cluster Manager dashboard.
Locate the newly created AWS Developer Service card (or the corresponding cloud provider you selected), and click on it to open the service details and launch the messaging console.

Step-8:Use Basic Authentication

To connect with your Solace Event Broker, either for testing within the console or integrating with SAP Cloud Integration (CPI)—you’ll need to authenticate using Basic Authentication.

From the “Try Me!” tab:

  • The Client Username is auto generated

  • The Client Password is masked but can be copied using the icon beside the field

  • These credentials allow you to publish and subscribe messages securely via the broker

These credentials are essential for establishing a secure connection from CPI to Solace using the AEM (Advanced Event Mesh) adapter, especially when sending data to queues or topics.

Step-9: Data Publishing Methods

  1. Topics (Publish/Subscribe Pattern)
  • Allows broadcasting messages to multiple subscribers.
  • Every subscriber listening to a topic receives a copy of the message.

Delivery Modes:

  • Direct: Messages are sent immediately and not stored in the broker.
  • Persistent: Messages are stored until acknowledged by the receiver.

  1. Queues (Asynchronous Processing)
  • Used to store and manage messages between systems.
  • You need to provide a Queue Name to place data in the queue.

Delivery Modes:

  • Direct: Messages are sent immediately and not stored in the broker.
  • Persistent: Messages are stored until acknowledged by the receiver.

Step-10:Subscribing to Data

Subscribing to data in Solace is a straightforward process once the connection is established. It uses the same authentication credentials as the publisher to ensure consistency and security.

  • Use the same client username and password that were used to publish messages.

  • After a successful connection, navigate to the Subscriber section in the Try Me! console.

  • Enter the exact topic path used during publishing. Solace uses hierarchical topic structures, so the path must match exactly for the subscriber to receive the intended messages.

Step-11:Verify Data and Status

After subscribing, you can check the data and its status at the bottom of the Subscriber Panel

Steps to Connect Solace to SAP CPI :

Step-1:

Go to the try me in the solace platform and copy the username and password in the solace that are provided.

Step-2: 

Go to your SAP Integration Suite and then go to the monitor page then go to the Security Material and add user credentials that copied for the solace.

Step-3: 

configure the sender Advance Event Mesh Adapter in the sap iflow 

Copy the Broker URL and username  from try me in the solace platform and give it in sap AEM sender adapter connection

Fill the required fields and select the Basic Authentication  and give the password secure alias name as we given in the security material

In this way we can configure the solace to the sap cpi using Advance Event Mesh sender and Receiver Adapter

This guide walked you through the complete setup of Solace Event Broker, from account creation to message publishing and subscription and sending data from sap and receiving from the solace.
With topics, queues, and authentication configured, you now have a solid foundation for event-driven messaging.

entry.title: A Rundown of API Lifecycle in SAP BTP: End - End tutorial for beginners
entry.content:
Introduction: In this weblog, I'll give you a rundown of API lifecycle in SAP BTP - beginning with how to create an API Provider, API Proxy, testing a Product through the Developer Portal.

(I) Create API Provider: For creating an API provider first go to Configure>>APIs>>API Providers>>Click on Create>>Give the details like name, host, authentication>> then save it and test the connection.

(II) Create API Proxy:  Select the API Provider which you have created above then select the service from the available list for your Api Provider.

Specify the Proxy Details: name>title>>base path>>version>> click on create and review the target endpoint and resources>>then save it>>Deploy it for activation of your API proxy.

(III)  In this step we need to add policies click on the policies>>edit>>flows>>TargetEndpoint>>PostFlow

Here, I have added two policies one is Assign Message Policy and another is Basic Authentication.

In Assign message policy- 

(i)add name 

(ii) the XML, editor give your username and password  

 

 

Now you have to add Basic Authentication Policy here you have to add the name and check these details like Endpoint type, flow type and stream.

Then Click on update>>save>>redeploy it again.

(IV) For Creating a Product - Engage>>Product>>Create

Then move to APIs tab press on add button>> now choose the API which you have created earlier>>click on OK button and then publish it

entry.title: What's New in SAP BTP – Q2 2025
entry.content:
Q2 was another big quarter for SAP Business Technology Platform. From application development to integration and analytics, we are excited to share how SAP BTP continues to simplify, streamline, and speed things up! Let's dive into some of the top innovations!

App Dev & Automation Highlights 

Simplified SAPUI5 extensions with the SAP Build Extensibility Wizard 

If your business relies on cloud ERP as its IT backbone, you know it may need extensions to meet unique requirements. When built-in extensibility isn’t enough, SAP Build on SAP BTP offers powerful options for custom coding and SAP Fiori UI extensions.  

Now, with the SAP Build Extensibility Wizard, you can create UI extensions directly from your cloud ERP application. By launching the Extensibility Wizard directly from your SAP Fiori application, you are given different options for the type of extension you want to create.

The 'User Interface Extension' lets you either adapt the existing Fiori app or create a new custom application. By setting up your destinations and details in the Wizard, you can either remove sections, add new fields, and create a completely new variant of the application with SAP Build Code and Business Application Studio. Developers and key users can already use it to create custom processes and now, custom user interfaces. 

Watch the video demo (starting at 0:08)  for more insights!   

Learn more:  Simplify SAPUI5 Code Extensions with the SAP Build Extensibility Wizard

Application to Enable Business Users to Manage Decisions

To empower business users to view or maintain decisions within SAP Build Process Automation, we launched a dedicated, purpose-built application that can be accessed directly from SAP Build Work Zone – without the need of IT. 

Business users can access a dedicated application in SAP Build Work Zone to manage decisions within a single project. Users can open the decision table, modify values directly, or import data from Excel and then save their changes, seeing only what matters and making the experience clean and focused. The release of a changed version is only one click away. Any errors are shown in the design console, letting users view the different versions of the project. 

See for yourself in the demo (starting at 2:05)  for more insights!

Learn more 

  • Configure the Stuido Home Application 
  • Using the Studio Home Application

Partner Solutions as an Installable Product on SAP BTP ABAP Environment 

Good news for SAP partners developing apps with SAP BTP ABAP Environment: you can now offer your solution not only as a multitenant Software as a Service solution, but also as an installable product! 

Customers can now install the solution directly in their system as a product. As a part of SAP BTP ABAP Environment, the Landscape Portal supports both delivery options: multitenant SaaS and installable product. 

You can do this in three easy steps:

  1. Build your product with the Register Product app. 
  2. Choose your delivery model: 
    • For multitenant SaaS, configure it in the Maintain Solution app  
    • For installable product, use the Publish Product app. 
  3. Publish your solution to the SAP Store with a PartnerEdge Build contract and an SAP Store enhancement. 

Now customers using SAP BTP ABAP Environment can find your product in the SAP Store and install it into their own system using the Deploy Product option. 

For detailed guidance, watch the demo (starting at 3:42). 

Learn more: Building partner products on SAP BTP ABAP Environment

Integration Highlight

Describe Externalized Parameters of an Integration Flow 

In SAP Integration Suite externalization enables integration developers to define parameters as variables for certain configurations of adapters or flow steps of an integration flow. The values of these parameters can be changed without editing the integration flow, for example, when moving integrations from development or test environment to production. To simplify the understanding of this difficult and technical process, content developers can now provide descriptions directly in the integration flow editor. These can be the potential values, examples or additional details explaining the impact of specific values which will then be visible for guiding through each of the fields in the Configure view. This brings huge potential to improve the maintainability and reusability of your integration scenarios.  

Take a look at the demo (starting at 5:21) and see for yourself! 

Learn more: Externalized Parameters View

Data & Analytics Highlight

Analytical insights in Joule 

Joule, SAP's copilot, now enables you to get quick analytical answers without having to build reports. This provides you with valuable insights, saving time and giving you the information you need. 

Joule scans available data sources and suggests a few options, making comparisons to previous months easier. Joule updates the view right away, making it easy to see how things are trending. For example, you can ask for the top ten sales agents, check the monthly commission trend from January to March, giving you contextual and relevant answers 

See this in action in the demo (starting 7:15).

Learn more: Introducing Analytical Insights in Joule: Empowering Smarter Decisions, Instantly

Cross Platform Highlight

Provision App-Specific Groups in Identity Directory 

SAP Cloud Identity Services tenant enables immediate provisioning of authorizations to target systems in SAP Analytics Cloud target system. You can  centrally manage user-group assignments linked to application-specific policies, triggering provisioning jobs that synchronize access rights efficiently and securely. This ensures users gain prompt access to their designated roles in the target system.

Watch the demo (starting at 8:37) for a closer look. 

Learn more: SAP Cloud Identity Services

Share your thoughts 

These videos are for YOU. We would love to hear your impressions. How do you like the video? How can we improve the upcoming videos? Please share your feedback by liking this post or leaving a comment below.

Thank you for your support and happy viewing, sharing, and enjoying!

You Might Also Be Interested In

  • SAP BTP Garage: monthly LIVE webinar with hands-on use case walkthroughs and demos.
  • SAP BTP Talk Podcast: monthly podcast covering all things SAP BTP.

entry.title: We asked, you answered. Customer views on SAP BTP.
entry.content:
A little over three years ago the SAP BTP team decided to develop a review page for SAP BTP with Trust Radius, a leader in enterprise software reviews, so that we might capture some feedback directly from customers concerning their satisfaction with their investment in SAP BTP, and which we hoped would also include their thoughts about the effect that use of the platform and its services was having on their own businesses.

Having now surpassed over 500 reviews, and even more ratings, as well as collecting several awards on the way, including the recent “Top Rated 2025” award among others, I thought that now would be a good time to reflect on some of the feedback that customers have left in their reviews of SAP BTP. 

So, here’s the first of what I hope will be a series of blogs which will look at some of the reviews that customers have left with Trust Radius about their experience with SAP BTP.  And I’ve decided to do this by taking a look from different organizational viewpoints, given that reviews have been left by individuals from various roles, in different parts of the business, and from organizations of all sizes.

SAP BTP in customers’ words

Let’s start with reviews from different types and sizes of organizations, and in in our customers’ own words here’s what they say:

“(Company) uses BTP to manage HTML applications that are then displayed in a customer and supplier portal, we also use BTP to manage users accessing the portal and all this connected to a S4/HANA…SAP Business Technology Platform is the right tool to manage sites, applications, users and everything you can imagine in the cloud and non-cloud world, from my point of view BTP is very well focused and has everything that a tool has to have and today” Large media production organization, 5*review, 10000+ employees, June 2025

“SAP Business Technology Platform is being used in our organization …It's low code/ no-code so easier to integrate HANA server with non-SAP server for data sync and rapid development of the product for the production. It helps us to get real time insight of data…we connected our SAP servers like mm, litmos to the legacy system we have like dynamics and salesforce, which helped us a lot during data migration and system integration. It helps the entire business automation process. Easier to analyze and manage the data with beautiful dashboard. After having this much still it's cost effective” Mid-sized engineering company 5* review, 501-1000 employees, April 2025

“BTP is used to improvise customer experience and creating automated processes across line of business and also enhancing the data and for the advanced analytics for helping in better decision-making and also BTP is a key tool for enabling the digital transformation to achieve better integration for creating more value for data and seamless flow between SAP and non SAP applications” Large IT & services business 5* review, 1001-5000 employees, May 2025

Of course, these are just a few of many reviews hosted on the SAP BTP page on the Trust Radius platform, and my selection criteria was simply one of organizational size. But even within just this small sample of customer reviews, it’s clear that SAP BTP is being used for different use cases across these differing organizations, but still delivering value through integration, automation and analytics capabilities.

Next time I’ll take a look from another viewpoint, but meanwhile, if you’re already intrigued and wish to see for yourself how customers are using SAP BTP then please feel free to browse the library of SAP BTP reviews on Trust Radius, or read more about SAP BTP on our website.

Happy reading!

Chris Grundy, Product Marketing, SAP BTP

entry.title: Integration Advisor – new B2B Library content for GS1 EANCOM, cXML and ASC X12
entry.content:
I would like to share with you an update regarding B2B Library versions included in the Integration Advisor (of SAP Integration Suite) offering: Recently we have added the newest versions for ASC X12 and cXML. Moreover, we have done some smaller improvements for the GS1 EANCOM Library.

The picture above depicts the overall building blocks of Integration Advisor. This blog post mainly relates to the Type Systems (B2B Library) area.

B2B Libraries in Integration Advisor

Integration Advisor provides you with the Message Definitions and Codelist collections for frequently used B2B Message Standards.

Our offering currently includes the predominantly used B2B Standards ASC X12 and UN/EDIFACT plus other EDI Libraries like Odette, TRADACOMS, GS1 EANCOM and the Automotive EDIFACT subsets (for JAIF, Odette and VDA) plus the B2B XML standards cXML, GS1 XML and xCBL. Based on these standard definitions, you can create and maintain your own customized Message Implementation Guidelines (MIGs) and implement Mapping Guidelines (MAGs).

The application also offers frequently used Codelists like the ISO Codelists, UN/CEFACT Codelists, GS1 Codelists and Automotive Codelists (from JAIF, Odette and VDA). You can use these codelists to make the specification of your MIGs even more descriptive.

You can find all this predefined content in the Library of Type System section of the Integration Advisor. 

New Versions for ASC X12

For ASC X12 we have added the versions 008050 & 008060 and now offer altogether 40 versions (from 002001 to 008060).

New Versions for cXML

For cXML we have included the versions 1.2.065 and 1.2.066 – which brings the number of supported versions to 30 (from 1.2.037 to 1.2.066).

GS1 EANCOM - additional display of underlying UN/EDIFACT versions 

GS1 EANCOM® is a GS1 subset of the UN/EDIFACT standard. Subset means that GS1 EANCOM messages are derived from and are compatible to UN/EDIFACT messages but omit optional elements that are not relevant for the industries and use cases targeted by GS1.

The GS1 organization has developed an EANCOM versioning scheme that consists of three parts:

  • EANCOM Release/Version (e.g. 1997 S3 Edition 1999)
  • Underlying Standard UN/EDIFACT Version (e.g. D.96A S3)
  • EANCOM Version Code (e.g. EAN008)

For example, the message ORDERS EAN008 can be implemented by either EANCOM Release 1997 S3 or 1997 S3 Edition 1999. Both are defined on top of the underlying Standard UN/EDIFACT Release D.96A S3. (Note: The EANCOM version codes (like EAN008) are message-specific version codes. For example, ORDERS EAN008 belongs to EANCOM Release 1997 S3 or 1997 S3 Edition 1999 (based on Edifact D.96A S3), while DESADV EAN008 is part of EANCOM Release 2002 S3 Edition 2016 (based on Edifact D.01B S3).)

In Integration Advisor, the content for GS1 EANCOM is organized according to the EANCOM Release/Version as officially defined by the GS1 Organization. Please see the screenshot below for the EANCOM versions offered in Integration Advisor. When you open a specific EANCOM version and navigate to the tab Overview, you can also find the underlying Standard UN/EDIFACT Version (e.g. D.96A S3). But it seems that this information was a bit too hidden, and we received multiple questions around EANCOM and UN/EDIFACT versions.

Therefore, we have done a small extension of our content. The underlying UN/EDIFACT Version is now immediately visible on the list of EANCOM versions. Refer to the green box in the screenshot above.

Additionally, please also check out this help page: https://help.sap.com/docs/cloud-integration/sap-cloud-integration/overview-of-b2b-standards > Section EANCOM. There you find (in the first table) again all EANCOM Versions together with their underlying UN/EDIFACT Version. And the third table helps you to match the EANCOM Version Code of a message to the correct EANCOM Release(s). For example, if you need the EANCOM message ORDERS based on D.96A, the first table points you to the 1997 S3 series (1997 S3 or 1997 S3 Edition 1999 or 1997 S3 Edition 2001). If you additionally know that you need ORDERS with code EAN008, then the third table tells you more specifically to either use 1997 S3 or 1997 S3 Edition 1999.

GS1 EANCOM - improved handling for EANCOM-specific code values associated with UN/CEFACT codelists 

The UN/EDIFACT standard recommends using the UN/CEFACT (UN/ECE) codelists (like Recommendation 24) for a couple of data elements. In Integration Advisor, these data elements are automatically linked to the according UN/CEFACT recommendation.

Previously, Integration Advisor had also provided the same links to UN/CEFACT codelists for the GS1 EANCOM Library. This is, however, not fully precise. The GS1 organization has modified the UN/CEFACT codelists for its own purposes by removing some standard code values and by adding additional EAN codes.    

In Integration Advisor, you will now find the link to both the standard UN/CEFACT codelist and the GS1-specific codelist. For an example, refer to the screenshot below. The EANCOM data element 4405 has a reference to both the EANCOM codelist 4405 and the UN/CEFACT codelist Recommendation 24. The screenshot nicely shows the mix of UN/CEFACT codes (like code 20) and EAN codes (like code 20E) in the EANCOM codelist.   

In the table below you find the list of affected data elements together with the assigned EANCOM and UN/CEFACT codelists: 

Data ElementDescriptionEANCOM CodelistUN/CEFACT CodelistAlternative GS1 Codelist
4053Delivery or transport terms4053Rec 5-
4277Payment terms4277Rec 17-
4405Transport status4405Rec 24TransportStatusConditionCode
6411Measurement units6411Rec 20 -
7065Package types7065Rec 21PackageTypeCode
8067Transport modes8067Rec 19TransportModeCode
8179Transport means8179Rec 28TransportMeansTypeCode

By the way, Integration Advisor also offers the Type System GS1 Codelists which provides general-purpose codelists published by GS1. The last column in the table above guides you to alternative GS1 codelists which you could use for some of the data elements instead.

Moreover, please note that the GS1 organization changed its design for the EANCOM codelists in 2016: 

  • Until 2014: The EANCOM codelists typically contain both the (reduced set of) code values from the UN/CEFACT codelist plus the additional EAN codes. Therefore, the EANCOM codelist is the preferable codelist and will be preselected in Integration Advisor once you create a new MIG.
  • From 2016: The EANCOM codelists now only contain the EAN codes (often only a few) but not the code values from the UN/CEFACT codelist anymore. As a result, we have decided that Integration Advisor offers the UN/CEFACT codelist as default codelist because it covers the majority of code values. If you need both UN/CEFACT and EAN codes together in your MIG, you would need to define your own Custom or MIG Codelist. Alternatively you can check if there is a GS1 Codelist available and if it contains all the code values you need. 

Conclusion

With this latest update, Integration Advisor has added the newest versions of ASC X12 and cXML and improved the content for GS1 EANCOM. This allows you to build your Message Implementation Guidelines (MIGs) and Mapping Guidelines (MAGs) based on all the released versions of these B2B Standards.

entry.title: Streamlining B2B Integration with AI-Powered SAP CPI: Accelerating Data Transformations
entry.content:
In today’s interconnected business ecosystem, seamless data exchange between systems is vital for operational excellence. SAP Cloud Platform Integration (CPI), a key component of the SAP Business Technology Platform (BTP), leverages AI-driven tools like the Integration Advisor to simplify complex B2B integrations, such as transforming EDI to IDoc formats. This article explores how Integration Advisor’s AI capabilities enhance accuracy and speed, provides a practical example of a B2B transformation, and explains how to implement it in SAP CPI Integration flows

Integration Advisor

The Integration Advisor, a cloud-based tool within SAP CPI, streamlines integration by automating the creation of Message Implementation Guidelines (MIGs) and Mapping Guidelines (MAGs). MIGs define source and target message structures (e.g., EDI and IDoc), while MAGs specify field mappings. Powered by machine learning, the Advisor analyzes industry standards, SAP metadata, and crowd-sourced patterns to propose mappings, validate data consistency, and provide reusable templates. This reduces manual effort, ensures compliance, and fosters collaboration across teams and partners.

Key Features of Integration Advisor

  • Automated Mapping Proposals: AI suggests field mappings based on standards and historical data.

  • Standard Libraries: Supports common B2B formats for rapid setup.

  • Collaboration Tools: Enables sharing of MIGs and MAGs for stakeholder alignment.

Benefits of AI-Assisted Integration

Integration Advisor’s AI capabilities deliver significant advantages:

  • Automation: Generates mappings for B2B transformations, reducing setup time by up to 60%.

  • Accuracy: Minimizes errors by 50–70% through data validation.

  • Scalability: Reusable templates support large-scale integrations.

  • Collaboration: Shared guidelines streamline coordination with partners.

Practical Example : Transforming EDI 850 to ORDERS05 IDoc

Consider a global retailer integrating a supplier’s EDI purchase order with its SAP S/4HANA system, which uses IDoc for order processing. Below are the steps

  1. Create MIGs: Define the source MIG for the EDI message, including segments like order details, partner information, and line items. Define the target MIG for the IDoc, covering segments like header, partner, and line items. 

    Now choose ASC XI2 as we will create MIG for EDI 850 first . 

    Now search for 850 which is for Purchase Orders  and then choose version 4010

    In the next step , choose without envelope which skips the Edi envelopes as they are not required for our POC . In the Next Step click on skip unless we have any EDI sample File to provide  and click next

    In the Next step , give the name to the MIG , direction is Inbound as EDI 850 is  inbound to ECC/ S4 . Also choose a business context accordingly and click on create 

     

    The MIG is created and we can choose the required segments for the structure and save it .

    The Get Proposals option leverages AI  and shows the confidence level for mapping and other related activities  . click on Save and then Activate 

    In order to get the CPI runtime Artifacts , click on Export > SAP Cloud Integration Runtime Artifacts . A Zip will be extracted which contains the multiple files which can be used in Integration flows 

ASC-X12_850_004010.xsd: An XSD (XML Schema Definition) file defining the structure and data types of the EDI 850 (ASC X12 004010) message. Used to validate the EDI input data against its expected format in SAP CPI.

X12-850_postproc.xsl: An XSLT (Extensible Stylesheet Language Transformations) stylesheet applied post-processing to transform or refine the EDI data after initial parsing. Used to adjust the output for compatibility with downstream systems.

X12-850_preproc.xsl: An XSLT stylesheet used for pre-processing the EDI 850 data before mapping. It handles tasks like segment normalization or data cleansing to prepare it for transformation.

X12-850_RD.xsd: An XSD file representing the runtime data model or reference structure for the EDI 850 message. Used by SAP CPI to ensure the transformed data adheres to the expected runtime schema.

X12-850_testdata_CPI.xml: An XML file containing sample test data for the EDI 850 message, formatted for CPI. Used to test and validate the integration flow within SAP CPI.

X12-850_testdata_EDI.txt: A text file with sample EDI 850 data in its raw format. Used as input for testing the parsing and transformation process.

X12-850_testdata_ICA.xml: An XML file with test data structured according to the Integration Content Advisor’s intermediate format. Used to verify the mapping logic during development.

 In a Similar way , we can create a MIG for ORDERS05 IDOC as well 

2.  Create MAG : To create MAG , Click on MAGs under Design and then click create > choose Standard MAGs

Now select the Source and target MIGs and then click on create 

Now the MAG is created as below and it doesn't have any mapping / transformation logic in it . 

Now , click on proposal which will provide us the list of mapping proposals generated . In our case , we had 600 + proposals generated with the help of AI . Now Select Best proposal and then use Only for Valid Mappings so that the proposals get imported to the mapping . 

If any mapping logic is required apart from proposals , we can manually add them as we do in normal message  mapping . We can stimulate the mapping using the stimulate option . 

Once Done , save and activate the MAG. Upon clicking export Option we can get the cpi runtime components .

Time and Cost Savings

Manually mapping EDI to IDoc can take 6–8 hours due to complex segment structures. Integration Advisor’s AI reduces this to 2–3 hours, achieving a 60–75% time savings. Error reduction of 50–70% minimizes rework, enhancing efficiency.

Drawbacks 

This functionality is not mature enough to provide proper proposals . Multiple conflicting proposals were there and multiple important segments didnt have any proposals at all. MIG is very useful to generate the xsds of EDI and other standard formats , whereas MAG is not that useful as MIGs

Why Integration Advisor Is Transformative

As businesses connect ERP systems, suppliers, and third-party platforms, the demand for rapid, reliable integrations grows. Integration Advisor addresses this by automating mappings, ensuring data integrity, and adapting to B2B standards. For example, a manufacturing firm reduced integration timelines from two weeks to four days using Integration Advisor, improving supplier order accuracy.

Best Practices for Success

  • Use Standard Libraries: Leverage metadata for accurate MIGs.

  • Validate Early: Test mappings with sample data to catch issues.

  • Collaborate: Share MIGs and MAGs for stakeholder alignment.

  • Monitor iFlows: Use SAP CPI’s tools to optimize performance and troubleshoot errors.

Conclusion

SAP CPI’s Integration Advisor, with its AI-driven capabilities, revolutionizes B2B connectivity by simplifying EDI-to-IDoc transformations. By automating mappings, reducing errors, and enabling seamless iFlow integration, it empowers enterprises to achieve operational excellence. Integration professionals should harness Integration Advisor and SAP CPI iFlows to streamline workflows and drive competitive advantage.

entry.title: Making the Case for Enhanced REST Adapter in SAP Integration Suite
entry.content:
Introduction

As organizations move toward API-first and cloud-centric architectures, RESTful integration has become a critical requirement for modern enterprise systems. SAP Integration Suite offers a native HTTPS adapter for basic REST scenarios, but many companies soon encounter limitations that hinder development agility, integration flexibility, and security compliance.

This article outlines why the Advantco REST Adapter is a strategic investment for organizations seeking to extend their SAP Integration Suite with robust, enterprise-grade REST capabilities.

1. Challenges with SAP's Native HTTP Adapter

SAP provides the HTTP Adapter for RESTful integrations. While functional for simple use cases, the adapter fall short in more demanding enterprise scenarios.

Limitations with SAP HTTP Sender Adapter:

  • Limited authentication support: Only Basic, OAuth 2.0 (Client Credentials), and Client Certificate
  • No proxy configuration support (Polling Mode)
  • Lacks advanced support for tokens, cookies, and dynamic authentication methods

Limitations with SAP HTTP Receiver Adapter:

  • Supports OAuth 2.0 Client Credentials and SAML Bearer Assertion, but lacks broader flow support (e.g., Implicit, Refresh Token, JWT)
  • Retry logic is basic; lacks pattern-based error handling (e.g., Error Response Contains)
  • Proxy configuration is supported but lacks UI-driven fine-tuning

These limitations increase the need for custom logic, external token handling, and complex iFlow structures—slowing delivery and increasing operational risks.

2. Advantco REST Adapter: Purpose-Built for Enterprise REST Scenarios

The Advantco REST Adapter enhances SAP Integration Suite with a comprehensive set of features tailored for modern REST APIs.

Capability

Advantco REST Adapter

SAP HTTP Adapter

OAuth2 (All flows), SAML, JWT, mTLS, Cookie, Session ID, Token, Client Certificate, Basic

JSON/XML conversion, multipart/form-data, binary, eXML attachments

Developer Tools

CORS Support

Not supported

3. OpenAPI Support: Accelerating API Lifecycle Management

One of the most critical features of the Advantco REST Adapter is native support for the OpenAPI specification:

  • Import OpenAPI/Swagger definitions to generate iFlows and mappings
  • Generate OpenAPI specs from inbound configurations
  • Expose APIs through Swagger UI for testing and documentation
  • Streamline governance with version-controlled API artifacts

This enables teams to build, test, and publish APIs rapidly while maintaining compliance with internal and external standards.

4. Security and Compliance

With support for enterprise-grade security protocols like OAuth2 (client credentials, authorization code, refresh token, implicit), SAML bearer tokens, JWT, mTLS, and platform-specific flows (Salesforce, Concur, SuccessFactors), the Advantco REST Adapter ensures secure API consumption and exposure.

It also supports dynamic token handling, cookie/session-based auth, client certificates, and user-role based authorization—offering a broader and more adaptable security posture than SAP’s native adapters.

5. Developer Experience: Advantco REST Workbench

The Advantco REST Workbench provides:

  • Seamless testing of REST services pre-integration
  • Dedicated validation for authentication and token flows
  • Auto-discovery of available endpoints within SAP IS
  • Parsing and publishing OpenAPI specifications
  • SwaggerHub-style UI for live testing and preview

This dramatically improves developer productivity and reduces pre-deployment errors.

6. Operational Efficiency and ROI

While the adapter involves licensing costs, the benefits far outweigh them:

  • Reduced custom development and maintenance
  • Faster partner onboarding through reusable templates
  • Improved SLA adherence with better error handling
  • Quicker resolution of integration failures
  • Increased reliability of polling-based REST integrations

A real-world customer case showed a significant reduction in development time and fewer post-go-live issues after migrating from SAP’s HTTPS adapter to Advantco’s REST Adapter.

7. Real-World Integration Scenarios

Scenario 1: FedEx REST API Integration for Shipment Tracking

A manufacturing company integrates SAP S/4HANA with FedEx’s REST API to retrieve real-time shipment status updates. The API requires OAuth 2.0 Client Credentials authentication, JSON payloads, custom headers, and compliance with an OpenAPI specification.

FedEx API Reference: https://developer.fedex.com/api/en-us/catalog/track/v1/docs.html

Challenges with SAP HTTPS Adapter:

  • Requires external token fetch logic and Groovy scripting
  • Lacks native support for JSON mapping and header manipulation
  • Cannot import OpenAPI spec or auto-generate interfaces
  • Lacks retry configuration for transient failures

Advantages of Advantco REST Adapter:

  • OAuth 2.0 token acquisition and injection is built-in
  • UI-based configuration of headers and JSON mapping
  • Full OpenAPI support enables auto-generation of interfaces
  • Retry logic and error handling out of the box

Benefits: With an advanced REST adapter, the FedEx shipment tracking integration benefits from built-in OAuth 2.0 token handling and UI-based JSON/header configuration—eliminating the need for Groovy scripting. OpenAPI support streamlines interface generation and speeds up development. Robust retry logic ensures reliable data retrieval, reducing failure points and improving operational resilience.

Scenario 2: Avalara AvaTax API – Tax Calculation in Checkout

An e-commerce company uses Avalara’s AvaTax REST API for calculating sales tax during checkout. The API requires basic auth, supports gzip-compressed requests, returns large JSON responses, and uses multipart responses. It also requires polling for updates and operates in a multi-node environment.

AvaTax API Reference: https://developer.avalara.com/api-reference/avatax/rest/v2/api-reference/

Challenges with SAP HTTPS Adapter:

  • No support for gzip compression or chunked transfer encoding
  • Cannot handle multipart responses or polling logic
  • No deduplication or node-safe polling in clustered environments

Advantages of Advantco REST Adapter:

  • Supports gzip and chunked encoding natively
  • Built-in polling mode with duplicate handling
  • Handles multipart responses and attachments seamlessly
  • Supports CORS and proxy configuration for global API access

Benefits: Using an advanced REST adapter enables seamless gzip compression, chunked transfer handling, and polling logic required for real-time tax calculation with Avalara AvaTax. It eliminates the need for custom scripts to manage multipart responses and ensures node-safe, deduplicated polling in multi-node SAP IS environments.

Scenario 3: SAP Ariba Operational Reporting API for Procurement Data

A global procurement team needs to retrieve purchasing reports from SAP Ariba using the Operational Reporting for Procurement API. The Ariba API requires OAuth 2.0 with access tokens, supports pagination, and expects large JSON responses with metadata fields. The reporting API also mandates use of View Templates to request specific datasets.

SAP Ariba API Reference: https://developer.ariba.com/api/operational-reporting-for-procurement

Challenges with SAP HTTP Adapter:

  • No native support for OAuth 2.0 token flows with metadata injection
  • Requires custom scripts to handle pagination and ViewTemplate-based queries
  • Lacks retry logic when responses are incomplete or malformed

Advantages of Advantco REST Adapter:

  • Built-in support for OAuth 2.0 token acquisition and header enrichment
  • Native handling of paginated queries using token chaining: the adapter extracts a "nextPageToken" using JSONPath, inserts it into the next request dynamically, and loops until no token is returned—all configured without scripting.
  • Pagination supports offset-based, token-based, or next-link-based patterns
  • Enhanced error handling with JSON response pattern matching and retry logic
  • Integration with OpenAPI simplifies onboarding and documentation

Benefits: Significantly reduced development time and more robust handling of paginated and token-authenticated data retrieval from Ariba

Conclusion

The SAP HTTP adapter is capable and reliable for many standard REST integration needs. However, for advanced scenarios involving dynamic authentication flows, token-based pagination, compressed or multipart payloads, and robust error handling, an enhanced REST adapter can offer substantial benefits. By reducing development time, simplifying complex integrations, and improving long-term maintainability, solutions like the Advantco REST adapter provide a strategic complement to SAP Integration Suite for organizations with high-volume, multi-cloud, or compliance-sensitive environments.

entry.title: SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition seamless integration with Shopify - Complete Setup and Demo Guide
entry.content:
Tired of Juggling Data Between SAP and Shopify? We’ve Got You Covered!

Managing data and business processes across SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition and Shopify can often be a challenging and time-consuming task — especially when done manually or through custom-built integrations. That’s why we’re excited to introduce a ready-to-use integration package powered by SAP Integration Suite, built to simplify and streamline your operations.

Designed specifically for B2C commerce scenarios, SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition Integration with Shopify integration package ensures:

  • Seamless data synchronization between SAP and Shopify
  • Automated workflows for key business processes
  • A reduction in manual tasks and potential errors

In this blog, we’ll start with a high-level overview of what the integration offers. Then, we’ll walk you through a step-by-step guide to setting up the package — so you can get your systems connected and running efficiently with minimal effort.

Note : SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition Integration with Shopify integration package accelerator isn’t just limited to B2C. Partners can extend the integration to support B2B use cases as well, tailoring it to fit the needs of more complex business models. The package is built with extensibility in mind, so partners can enhance it further to accommodate specific business requirements or tailor it to specific industry needs.

Overview of SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition Integration with Shopify Integration Package:

SAP provides a variety of pre-built integration accelerators via the SAP Integration Suite, all accessible through the SAP Business Accelerator Hub. Among these, we’ve developed a dedicated Shopify integration accelerator that enables a seamless connection between your Shopify storefront and SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition.

The  SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition Integration with Shopify integration package ensures real-time data consistency across both platforms by synchronizing key business objects such as:

  •  🛒  Product information
  •  📦  Inventory levels/Product Stock
  • 💲Product Prices & Discounts 
  •  👤  Customer information

By automating critical business processes like order creation, cancellations, and returns, the integration reduces manual effort, minimizes errors, and increases operational efficiency. It also synchronizes shipping and delivery details, helping you provide accurate and timely updates to customers — a key to delivering a superior B2C customer experience.

The Shopify Integration with SAP S/4HANA Cloud package is designed to integrate key end-to-end business processes between SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition and Shopify, enabling smooth, automated data flow and operational consistency across both platforms.

The following core business processes are supported out of the box:

📦 From SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition to Shopify:

  • ✅ Replicate Products – Ensure accurate and up-to-date product information is reflected in your Shopify storefront.
  • 📊 Replicate Product Stock – Keep inventory levels in sync to avoid overselling or stockouts.
  • 💲 Replicate Product Prices & Discounts – Automatically update pricing and promotional details in Shopify.
  • 🚚 Replicate Delivery Details – Provide timely and accurate shipping information to your customers via Shopify.

🛒From Shopify to SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition:

  • 👥 Replicate B2C Customers – Capture and transfer customer data from Shopify to SAP, enabling centralized customer management.
  • 🧾Replicate Orders – Seamlessly transfer incoming sales orders into SAP for fulfillment and processing.
  • ❌ Replicate Order Cancellations – Reflect cancelled orders in SAP for proper stock and financial reconciliation.
  • 🔁 Replicate Order Returns – Automatically push return details from Shopify into SAP to streamline reverse logistics.

Together, these integration flows deliver a robust, automated B2C commerce experience, reducing manual interventions and ensuring your front-end and back-end systems remain in sync.

🚀 How to Set Up the “Shopify Integration with SAP S/4HANA Cloud  Public Edition” Package

Integrating Shopify with SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition is now easier than ever — thanks to the pre-built accelerator available on the SAP Business Accelerator Hub. This step-by-step guide will help you configure and deploy the integration package using SAP Integration Suite, so your systems can work together seamlessly.

✅Prerequisites

Before you begin, ensure you have the following:

  • 🔑  An SAP Partner Account with access to SAP Integration Suite (via SAP BTP – Business Technology Platform).
  • 🧾 Access to SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition.
  • 🛍  A Shopify Partner or Merchant Account.
  • 📘  Basic knowledge of SAP BTP, Integration Suite and Shopify. 
  • 🌐  Access to SAP Business Accelerator Hub.
  • 📘Detailed Configure Guide - SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition Integration with Shopify Configuration Guide in SAP Business Accelerator Hub

 🛠️  Step 1: Set Up SAP Integration Suite instance using SAP Business Technology Platform (BTP) account.

  1. Log in to SAP BTP Cockpit.
  2. Create a Subaccount and enable Integration Suite:
    • Navigate to your Global Account > Subaccount.
    • Create or open an Integration Suite instance.
    • Assign relevant entitlements and Assign relevant roles
    • Use the Booster Enable Integration Suite to automate setup or configure manually
    • for more details refer to sap help documentation SAP Integration Suite | SAP Help Portal

📦 Step 2: Import the Shopify Adapter Package into SAP Integration Suite

  1. Goto SAP Integration Suite instance
  2. Go to Discover tab.
  3. Search for “Shopify Adapter for SAP Integration Suite”.
  • Click “Copy” to add / move the package to your Design workspace.

  • To Configure Shopify Adapter Installation - Installing the Shopify Adapter is a prerequisite to use the Integration Content. For adapter installation, refer to the “Shopify Adapter Guide” and to the “Shopify Adapter and Plug-in Installation Guide” and also refer to more details refer to section "Shopify Adapter Installation" in configuration guide SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition Integration with Shopify Configuration Guide in SAP Business Accelerator Hub.

🔄Step 3: Configure Shopify iFlows (Integration Flows) with API access relevant details.

  1. Go to Design > Integrations in the Integration Suite.
  2. Open the imported Shopify Integration Package.
  3. Select a relevant iFlow (e.g., Replicate Orders from Shopify to SAP S4HANA Cloud Public Edition).
  4. Configure the necessary Externalized Parameters and Connections, referencing the detailed documentation for each Integration Flow.
  5. To Configuration in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition - the mandatory configurations which need to be performed in the SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition before you can start implementing the configuration for Shopify API and configuring the Integration Content in SAP Integration Suite and for more details refer to section "Configuration in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition" in configuration guide SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition Integration with Shopify Configuration Guide in SAP Business Accelerator Hub.
  6. Sample configuration shown below.

      Shopify Receiver Adapter Connection Configuration

  • Shopify Base Url: https://<yourshop>.myshopify.com/
  • Shopify Secure Parameter: The name of the Shopify access token secure parameter 

       SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition Receiver Adapter Connection Configuration

  • SAP S/4HANA Cloud Base Url: https://<your-sap-s4-hana-instance-id>-api.s4hana.cloud.sap
  • Credential Name: The name of the SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition secure parameter 

🧩 Example Integration Flows:

  • Shopify ➜ SAP S4HANA Public Cloud Edition : Customer Replication, New Orders, Order Cancellations & Returns
  • SAP S4HANA Public Cloud Edition ➜ Shopify: Products, Inventory Synchronization, Stock Availability, Delivery Status

🚀Step 4: Deploy and Test the Integration Package in Integration Suite

  1. Deploy selected iFlows from your Design workspace.
  2. Monitor from Monitor > Integrations > Message Processing Logs.
  3. Perform test transactions: for more details refer to Demo section in the blog
    • Place a test order in Shopify.
    • Monitor the message logs and confirm data replication in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition: Sales Orders, Business Partners, Product Catalog

🔧 Extend or Customize the Package (Optional)

As a partner you can extend or tailor the integration through:

  • Customer Exits to plug-in your custom integration flows (Pre Exits and Post Exits in Intergration Flows)
  • Copy and modify the integration content.
  • Groovy scripts to customize payload mappings.
  • Content Modifiers to apply business logic.
  • Enhanced error handling and alerting.

 💡 Partner Tips & Monetization Opportunities

As an SAP Partner, you can:

  • 💡 Extend the integration flows and Build new integration flows using SAP Shopify adapte
  • 📜  Demo your solution with real-time order sync and inventory updates, build a demo to show real-time sync between Shopify and SAP with custom business case.
  • 🧰 Buildc Multi-Tenant Integration Templates for reuse across customers.
  • 🧠 Leverage SAP Integration Advisor for intelligent mapping.
  • 💡  Add your branding, services, or vertical-specific enhancements.

High Level Demo Flow to showcase Order processing along with Master data replication.

  • Step 1 : View the SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition Integration with Shopify integration package in Integration Suite
  • Step 2: Show product in SAP S/4HANA CLOUD PUBLIC EDITION  (to be replicated to shopify)
  • Step 3: Start replication of product in integration suite
  • Step 4: Show replicated product in Shopify and add picture and select the sales channel to be online store and activate the product
  • Step 5: Log into shopify as customer and browse through existing products
  • Step 6: Select the product replicated from SAP S/4HANA CLOUD PUBLIC EDITION and add to basket
  • Step 7: Enter the relevant details like payment and create order
  • Step 8: Check the order created in shopify
  • Step 9: Replicate the order from shopify to SAP S/4HANA CLOUD PUBLIC EDITION
  • Step 10: Log into SAP S/4HANA CLOUD PUBLIC EDITION as internal_sales_rep and look for “Manage Sales Order Version 2” app and open the sales order and change the order date to todays date (both in header and item level) and Save sales order
  • Step 11: Log into SAP S/4HANA CLOUD PUBLIC EDITION as shipping_specialist and open app “Create outbound delivery with order reference”
  • Step 12: Enter shipping point and enter the sales order and shipping date as todays date and save , note down the Outbound Delivery ID
  • Step 13: Open app “pick outbound delivery” and enter Outbound Delivery ID and enter Actual GI Date DD/MM/YYYY (valid date, example 07/01/2025) , enter picking quantity as 1 and save
  • Step 14 : Click on Post GI and status of Outbound Delivery picking changes to Completely Processed. Note : show the SO Process flow of created order in SAP S/4HANA CLOUD PUBLIC EDITION
  • Step 15 : Replicate the Outbound delivery from SAP S/4HANA CLOUD PUBLIC EDITION public to Shopify .
  • Step 16: Open sales order in Shopify and show the OD created in SAP S/4HANA CLOUD PUBLIC EDITION reflected in metadata fields of Sales order and status of Sales Order is changed to fulfilled.

Detailed Demo steps:

Shopify Demo systems include the following systems - Integration Suite Tenant [along with BTP Sub-Account), SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, Shopify Admin Portal, Shopify Customer Portal

Step 1:  Access the  Integration Suite tenant and view “SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition Integration with Shopify” integration package

  • Open Integration Suite
  • Navigate to “Discover” -> “Integration”
  • Search for integration Package “SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition Integration with Shopify”  , view the integration flows and details.          

Step 2: Access to SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition System to show the replicating product master

  • Access system using URL SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition system as Product Master Specialist
  • Login with user = prodmaster_specialist
  • Launch the App : “Manage Product Master Data”  and search for Product ID  (sample product ID - TG11_PH_CW12)
  • Note: in the demo product replication integration flow we are replicating only one product with product ID (sample product ID - TG11_PH_CW12) and user could decide to replicate all products / sub-set of products, based on specific functional requirements.

Step 3: Start replication of product in Integration Suite

  • Open Integration Suite
  • Navigate to Discover -> Integration (only first time)
  • Search for integration Package “SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition Integration with Shopify”  , open the integration package -> copy the package
  • Navigate to Design -> Integration and API’s
  • Search for integration Package “SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition Integration with Shopify”  ,
  • Navigate to “artifacts” and search for integration package “Replicate Products from SAP S4HANA Cloud Public Edition to Shopify”
  • Deploy the integration flow “Replicate Products from SAP S4HANA Cloud Public Edition to Shopify”
    • To deploy => click on the “3 dots” of integration package and select “deploy”
    • Deploy would start the product replication from SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition to Shopify      

Step 4: Show replicated product in Shopify and add picture and select the sales channel to be online store and activate the product

  • Login using URL : Shopify 
  • Navigate to “Products”
  • Check and prepare the product for selling to customer
    • Check the product is replicated
    • Add the picture to publish (click on “Media” and click on “+” and select the relevant picture”
  • Add the sales channel as online store ( click on “Manage” in “Publishing” section, in the popup select “online store”  and click on “include” and click on “done” )
  • Set the status of the product to be “Active” and “Save” the product
  • Note: for the product to be visible for customer in shopify portal for purchasing , the status must be set to “Active” and sales channel to be set to “online store”.      

Step 5: login to shopify as customer and browse through existing products

Step 6: select the product replicated from SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition and add to basket

  • Purchase the product (sample product ID - TG11_PH_CW12)
  • Select the product from catalog
  • Click on “Add to Cart” and click on “Checkout”
  • Account and ShipTo address would be filled automatically with the logged in user details

Step 7: enter the relevant details like payment and create order

  • Enter the Credit Card Details : Card Number, Expiration Date, Security Code
  • Click on “Pay Now”  , order would be placed         

Step 8: check the order created in shopify

  • Navigate to “Orders”
  • Check the order created with fulfillment status “Unfulfilled” , note down the “SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition Order ID”  , order ID would be used to search order created in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition system      

Step 9: replicate the order from shopify to SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition

  • Open Integration Suite
  • Navigate to Design -> Integration and API’s
  • Search for integration Package “SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition Integration with Shopify”  , open the integration package -> navigate to Artifacts , search for artifact “Replicate Orders from Shopify to SAP S4HANA Cloud Public Edition”
  • Deploy the integration flow “Replicate Products from SAP S4HANA Cloud Public Edition to Shopify”
  • Replication of orders in status Unfulfilled would be moved to SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition .
  • Note: to check the status of replication by navigating to “Monitor” => “Integration and API’s” , check for “logs”      

Step 10: Log into SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition system as Sales Representative

  • open for “Manage Sales Order Version 2” app
  • open the sales order and change the “Requested Delivery Date” to todays date (both in header and item level) and Save sales order
  • Note: delivery date to be changed to today’s date, since user want to complete the delivery of the order today by creating outbound delivery today.       
     

Step 11: Log into SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition as Delivery shipping specialist and complete the delivery of Order

  • open for “Create outbound delivery with order reference” app

Step 12: Enter the key details like Shipping Point and Sales Order ...

  • enter shipping point sample as 3810 (select shipping point relevant for your use-case) and enter the sales order ID create earlier and Selection Date would be defaulted to todays date
  • click on “continue” and click on “save”
  • note down the outbound delivery ID

Step 13: Delivery shipping specialist will pic the outbound delivery

  • open app “pick outbound delivery” and enter “Delivery” id and enter “Actual GI Date DD/MM/YYYY (valid date, example 07/01/2025) , enter “picking quantity” as 1 and click on “save”         

Step 14 : Delivery shipping specialist will Post Goods Issue for the corresponding outbound delivery

  • click on “Post GI” and status of Outbound Delivery picking changes to “Completely Processed”.      

Note : show the Sales Order “Process flow” of created order in SAP S/4HANA Cloud  Public Edition for the corresponding order, the process flow gives visual representation of business entities created in the system (Order, Outbound Delivery, Invoice …)

Step 15 : replicate the Outbound delivery from S4 public to Shopify .

  • Open Integration Suite
  • Navigate to Design -> Integration and API’s
  • Search for integration Package “SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition Integration with Shopify”  , open the integration package -> navigate to Artifacts , search for artifact “Replicate Orders from Shopify to SAP S4HANA Cloud Public Edition”
  • Deploy the integration flow “Replicate Delivery Details from SAP S4HANA Cloud Public Edition to Shopify”
  • Replication of outbound delivery from SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition system would be moved to Shopify and corresponding Order status would updated to “fulfilled” in Shopify
  • Note: to check the status of replication by navigating to “Monitor” => “Integration and API’s” , check for “logs”         

Step 16: open sales order in shopify and check the  status of Order, it should be changed from “Unfullfilled” to “fulfilled”

  • Navigate to “Orders”
  • With the successfully delivery , the order should be fulfilled and order status should be “Fulfilled” , note the fields “SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition Order ID”  and “SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition Outbound Deliveries”  in order would be copied from SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition system          

The above steps completes the High Level Demo Flow which showcase the order processing along with product master data replication.

Note: The  SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition Integration with Shopify integration package covers Order Returns and Order Cancellation business scenarios along with Order Processing, please feel free to explore the other business process like Order Returns and Order Cancellation .

entry.title: Setup Event Mesh – Integration Suite (EMIS) to Trigger Events from S4H Cloud to CPI via Webhooks
entry.content:
In this blog, we’ll walk through a step-by-step guide to setting up SAP Event Mesh – Integration Suite (EMIS) to enable real-time event-driven communication between SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud (S4HC) and Cloud Integration.

This tutorial covers the flow from configuring Event Mesh - Integration Suite to receive events from S/4HANA Public Cloud and briefly touches upon a sample HTTP based endpoint exposed by a SAP Cloud Integration (CPI) iFlow to which the events are pushed via Webhooks. Below Solution Diagram depicts the message flow. Please note that Queue 2 is presented solely for illustrative purposes and is not discussed within the scope of this article.

Solution Diagram-

 

Whether you're new to SAP’s Event-Driven Architecture or looking to integrate cloud systems in a more responsive and scalable way, this guide will provide you with a clear and practical implementation path.

 

Prerequisites-

  1. Available only for SAP Integration Suite standard and premium editions
  2. If present, remove the instance of Standalone Event Mesh (Default Plan) from your Subaccount
  3. Integration Suite service is already subscribed to in the subaccount
  4. Integration Suite Event Mesh is added as an entitlement in the Global account

Refer SAP Note 3461547 for more details like Region Availability.

 

Detailed Steps-

  1. Go to BTP Tenant’s Integration Suite instance.   

             

       2. Click on Manage Capabilities

       3. Click on Add Capabilities

       4. Click on Manage Business Events and then click on Next

       5. Click Activate

           It’s now Active

      6. Click on OK and proceed

We can now see the Manage Business Events tile. But none of the hyperlinks are yet active. This is because the necessary roles are still to be added to your user.

        7. Go back to your BTP Subaccount and go to Security -> Users option

        8. Search for your user and click on it

        9. Click on Assign Role Collection.

      10. Search for Event in the search bar. This will display 2 Integration Suite Event Mesh specific roles. Select both these roles and click on Assign Role Collection.

           Both these roles are now assigned to your user.

      11. Refresh the Integration Suite screen. We can now see the hyperlinks for Configure Events and Monitor Events in the Manage Business Events tile as shown below

      12. Click on Configure Events link.

This will open the below screen. Click on Activate to enable Event Mesh capability

 

A notification will appear confirming that event mesh is successfully activated.

 

Wait for some time, event mesh will now show as active-

 

If it shows as failed here, you might want to check the 2nd point under Prerequisites, where it has been suggested to remove the instance of Standalone Event Mesh (Default Plan) from your Subaccount, if applicable in your case.

13. Click on Queues tab to create a new queue. Click on Create button.

14. Give a name to the queue and click on Create-

15. Go to SAP BTP Subaccount and create a Messaging Client to receive messages from Topics in S4H Public Cloud

16. Create a space named “INTEGRATION_TOOLS”, or any other name of your choice. Use an existing space, if already available.

 

Note that this step needs the “Integration Suite Event Mesh” entitlement to be added in Global account as mentioned in the Prerequisites section.

 

17. Click on Create to create an Instance of Event Mesh-

Select Service as “SAP Integration Suite, Event Mesh” and other parameters as shown below. Take note of the Instance Name you provide, since this would be needed later during S4HANA Public Cloud configurations.

Instance creation will show as In progress initially-

Click on the Message Client “em-client-s4h” when it’s created-

  1. Click on Create under Service Keys

Give it an appropriate name and click on Create

Copy this JSON content for use later in S4HC while creating the communication arrangement.

19. Move over to S4HCloud system and open Communication Arrangements app. Click on New.

Search for Scenario 0092, which is meant for Enterprise Eventing Integration.

Give an appropriate name to the arrangement, assign user “CPI” (or any other comm user as suitable in your case) and paste the Service Key we created earlier and click on create.

This will throw the below error message, which is expected. This error is thrown because we haven’t given any Topic namespace which will help S4HCloud to post this correctly to the Message Client we created in BTP when it is subscribed to a Topic in S4HCloud.

Click on close.

Add a namespace field with a value as em/client/s4h. This name is similar to the Message Client name. Just replace the “-” with “/”

Add it back to the Service Key and click on Create.

This is now displaying the new Communication Arrangement that has been created. You can now see the topic space added.

20. Add these 2 apps – Enterprise Event Enablement (Event Monitor) and Enterprise Event Enablement (Configure Channel Binding) to your home screen in S4HC

21. Go to Enterprise Event Enablement (Configure Channel Bindings)

22. Click on Channel “EMIS_0092” which was generated in the previous step

23. Click on Create under Outbound Topic Bindings

24. Search for Events-

/sap/s4/beh/businesspartner/v1/BusinessPartner/Changed/v1

/sap/s4/beh/businesspartner/v1/BusinessPartner/Created/v1

Click these one by one and click on Create

 

 

 

You can now see both the Topics are added to the outbound channel “EMIS_0092”.

S4HC is now ready to send Business Partner - Create and Change events.

25. Go back to the Queue in BTP to subscribe to these 2 Topics

Click on the queue Tab

26. Go to Subscriptions tab and click on Create

27. Paste the Topic names here one by one.

Note that the topic subscription should have the format - namespace + /ce + /topic name

Example in our case-

em/client/s4h + /ce + /sap/s4/beh/businesspartner/v1/BusinessPartner/Created/v1

You need to manually paste these 2 Topics

em/client/s4h/ce/sap/s4/beh/businesspartner/v1/BusinessPartner/Changed/v1

em/client/s4h/ce/sap/s4/beh/businesspartner/v1/BusinessPartner/Created/v1

Do it for each of the Topics and click on Create

You can now see the 2 Topics being subscribed to.

28. Go to Overview tab of Event Mesh and click on the Message Client “em-client-s4h”

This will open the Webhooks configuration screen. Click on Create.

Use the below HTTP CPI iFlow Endpoint as the Webhooks URL-

https://<TenantURL>/http/BPReplicationToSalesforce

You need to create a CPI iFlow with a HTTP Sender Channel, whose endpoint will then act as a Webhooks URL as shown above.

Click on Create

The webhooks should now forward any messages that appear in this queue to the iFlow meant for SAP to Salesforce BP sync.

Below is a sample CPI iFlow that was used for this Demo. You can implement as per your requirement.

Brief details of the CPI iFlow Steps-

  1. Business Events Message is received via a HTTP Sender Adapter.

The payload format of the incoming event notification payload is as given in the below SAP API Business Accelerator link.

https://api.sap.com/event/CE_BUSINESSPARTNEREVENTS/resource

       2. The BP number needs to be extracted from this payload.

       3. A call needs to be made to S4HC Business Partner OData API to fetch additional details for the Created or Changed Business Partner.

       4. Map to the corresponding structure of Accounts object of Salesforce

       5. Finally, send the payload to Salesforce API.

 

This completes the configuration setup, enabling the integration to capture and forward any Business Partner updates to the downstream systems.

As shown in the Solution Diagram earlier, you can create additional queues for other subscribers who are interested in receiving the same or other events and subscribe them to the required Topics of interest.

 

Scaling Up with Advanced Event Mesh (AEM)-

As your message size requirements grow, you can seamlessly transition to the more robust Advanced Event Mesh (AEM), which offers enhanced scalability and performance as compared to Integration Suite - Event Mesh (EMIS).

Refer below materials-

https://learning.sap.com/learning-journeys/discovering-event-driven-integration-with-sap-integration-suite-advanced-event-mesh/examining-sap-integration-suite-advanced-event-mesh_ce4073de-a466-4ac3-a2bc-4324b8b08b26

https://help.sap.com/docs/sap-integration-suite/advanced-event-mesh/what-is-sap-integration-suite-advanced-event-mesh

 

We have now reached the end of this blog post. I hope you found the content useful and that it helped clarify the setup and capabilities of SAP Integration Suite’s Event Mesh. Whether you're just starting with event-driven architecture or exploring advanced options like Advanced Event Mesh (AEM), I’d love to hear your thoughts.
